Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Coordinated Experiments and Simulations of Near-Surface Turbulent Flow over Barchan Dunes: Informing Models of Dune Migration and Interaction

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Christensen, Kenneth / Best, James / Anderson, William
Proposal Number: 1603211 / 1604155 / 1603254

The focus of the proposed research is to explore the migration of sand dunes in large scale, desert environments or ocean floor environments. The proposed collaborative approach involves experiments, theory and simulations to understand the process of dune migration under turbulent flow. The findings of this work can be important for Aeolian dune migration, a problem that can be critical to predicting and mitigating desertification as it occurs in the Western US and in other places in the world.

Understanding and predicting the morphodynamics of subaqueous barchan dunes is critical for management of waterways and quantifying transport of nutrients and pollutants. Similarly, understanding these processes for aeolian barchan dunes is important for characterizing desertification processes and for informing numerical weather prediction. At large dune spacings, barchan kinematics can be accurately predicted using sediment transport models predicated on mean bed shear stress. However, barchans typically occur in fields. Since dune migration rate is size dependent, a heterogeneous dune field will result in variable bedform spacing, with smaller (faster) dunes approaching larger (slower) dunes. Thus, when two dunes are in close proximity, the upstream one will produce an unsteady, turbulent wake that will sculpt the morphology of the downstream one, introducing significant morphological complexity owing to spatially-heterogeneous turbulence. Such effects are not captured by current state-of-the-art models. (These approaches simulate the bedform evolution but do not resolve the overlying flow; they instead use a spatially homogeneous representation of turbulence as the flow input). Informed by preliminary research, and compelled by deficiencies in existing dune modeling approaches, it is hypothesized that the "missing link" to elucidating the morphodynamics of interacting barchan dunes is the unsteady nature of the turbulence generated within the inter-dune space. It is proposed to pursue a collaborative research effort that leverages an innovative measurement protocol and scientific computing, complemented by observations in nature. The results will transform the understanding of dune-dune flow field interactions for fixed-bed dunes as a function of proximity and volumetric ratio and will form the basis for advancing morphodynamic models. Planar and volumetric PIV measurements will be conducted in a refractive-index-matched environment (allowing unprecedented optical access to the flow) for targeted dune configurations. These experiments will validate large-eddy simulations that will enable larger spatial volumes and a much broader suite of dune field parameters to be explored, with the latter informed by field observations. The culminating task will involve incorporating the turbulence heterogeneity identified into existing morphodynamic models to test the hypothesis. The proposed work will have an impact not only in fluid dynamics through its impact on engineering turbulent flows, but also to other disciplines including boundary-layer meteorology, geomorphology and sedimentology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary aim of this study has been to elucidate the structure of the turbulent flow associated with proximal barchan dunes, and how turbulence drives the morphodynamics aspects of the barchan—barchan interactions. Barchan dunes are three-dimensional, crescent-shaped bedforms which form across a wide range of vegetation deprived environments, including aeolian deserts, fluvial channels, continental shelves, and other planetary surfaces. As they migrate in the direction of the overlying wind or water flow, neighboring barchans will start to interact with each other prior to coming into direct contact. A common scenario involves smaller, faster migrating barchans overtaking and colliding with larger, slower moving barchans. Such collisions result in complex morphological changes and modified sediment erosion patterns, both of which are linked inextricably to the associated turbulent flow structure overlying the dunes.

In order to investigate these processes, flow measurements were made using particle image velocimetry (PIV) over representative configurations of solid barchan models in a flume environment. The bedform configurations in these experiments mimic the early stages of a laterally offset collision process, wherein a smaller upstream barchan approaches a larger downstream barchan. In addition, a baseline, isolated symmetric barchan case was investigated. To obtain full optical access, particularly to flow in the near-surface region, experiments were conducted in large-scale refractive index matching (RIM) flumes at the University of Notre Dame. These unique facilities enable uninhibited optical access to the flow field thus facilitating high-fidelity measurements which would be otherwise unfeasible in a canonical flow facility, such as a wind tunnel or water flume.

First, the baseline case was used and data was obtained from numerous measurements in several planes comprising all three orientations. The results reveal the complexity and three-dimensionality of the wake generated by an isolated barchan. Such flow, is then “imposed” by the upstream barchan on the downstream barchan in the collision scenarios. The separated shear layer in the wake of the upstream barchan is populated by large-scale 3D coherent structures that, after being generated by the upstream barchan, convect and eventually impinge onto the surface of the downstream barchan enhancing near-bed turbulent stresses. Such structures, shown in this study to take the form of both hairpin vortices shed in the wake and horseshoe vortices formed over the upstream face of the dunes, embody significant turbulent kinetic energy and thus the potential to mobilize sediment. As interdune spacing changes, both the flow separation characteristics and the spatial structure of the coherent motions are modified, with the lateral offset between the dunes inducing additional flow asymmetries.

This experimental effort was performed alongside numerical simulations conducted by collaborators at the University of Texas at Dallas, who investigated identical barchan dune interaction scenarios. With the advantage of being able to three-dimensionally resolve the flow field, they demonstrated complementary results concerning the structure of the turbulent flow field which agreed with the findings here.

Conceptual models of the vortex structure in the wake of an isolated barchan as well as in the interdune region of interacting barchans have been developed based on a combination of the results obtained from measurements made in all three planes over the course of the entire project. These results provide an important framework for interpreting observed morphodynamics of interacting barchan dunes and build a foundation for further study of important field-scale dynamics, as well as extensions to other three-dimensional bedforms.
